So this question can be resolved as yes under two scenarios: (1) the UK and Scottish governments agree on a Section 30 text and Holyrood sets a date, or (2) the Scottish (government or parliament) sets a date for a non-binding referendum. The chances of (1) by July 1 are slim but not zero - after the 69-59 vote, stubbornly opposing the will of the Scottish parliament may be seen as deeply undemocratic. The chances of (2) are higher, but not overwhelming either - a non-binding vote may be seen as a way to put pressure on the UK government to agree on Section 30, but also comes with the risk of low participation that might validate the UK's resistance. The most likely outcome seems continuing discussions, but no resolution by July 1. But if Theresa May agrees in principle to the idea of a referendum, Sturgeon can wait a bit for the date.

Okay, tricky question. Let's analyze the players first:
On the one hand, we have Nicola Sturgeon, the scottish PM. She has been beating the "we are leaving the UK" drum heavily since the Brexit result. From her perspective, she has two reasons for wishing to go ahead with this quickly. 
One: The earlier she manages to leave Britain, the more in sync Scottish law and EU law will be.
Second: If she manages to get a referendum quickly, she will have the highest chance of success. Since most scots voted against Brexit, the temporary emotions in all this would play in her favor. If she waits too long and Britain succeeds after leaving the EU, she would be in a much worse position. In addition, if she gets a referendum while Britain is busy with the Brexit process, she can be assured that her political opponents would be preoccupied, allowing her to campaign more easily.

It's possible that it may come down to specific wording within the legislation. It is my understanding that in the case of the Brexit legislation, Parliament ceded discretion to the PM to set the date. It is conceivable the Holyrood legislation might include some reference to a date, or a period of time. Thus the two legislations might not be directly comparable. Would not setting a time frame, or window, be setting a date? Again, if the mechanism is different (i.e., unlike the PM, the discretion of the First Minister might be limited), you can't really use the Brexit legislation as a comparable. One was not fixed in any way; the other might be fixed in some way.

Intention by the SNP is clear (aiming for Autumn 18-Spring 19). SNP short of outright majority so outcome will depend on (probably) Lib Dems. However, I believe that the Scottish Parliament (SP) does not have the power to decide on having a referendum, Westminster holds the power for that. Hence even if the SP votes FOR, there is a lot to be negotiated between Scottish and UK govt before a date is set. The answer to this question also depends on the meaning of "will Scotland set": technically the date will not be set by Scotland alone but by a combination of Westminster and SP decisions as well as a Royal Assent (if the same procedure is followed as previously). Given these complications, the probability for a definitive date as of 1/7/17 remains low but if the interpretation is "the date set by the SP", it is possible that it will happen by the deadline. Hard Brexit makes a second independence referendum very likely

1.  On 16 October 2016, the Scottish Government published a draft bill that would enable a second Scottish independence referendum to occur, after receiving legislative consent. The Scottish Independence Referendum Bill draft is largely similar to its sister act of 2013, and has been put out for consultation by the government to allow the public to convey their views on the wording and procedures of the bill.
2.  As the constitution is a 'reserved' matter under the Scotland Act 1998, for a future referendum on Scottish independence to be binding under UK law, it would need to receive the consent of the British Parliament to take place.
3.  The Scotland Act 1998 empowers the Scottish Parliament to legislate in policy areas devolved to Scotland, but one of its clauses obliges the Scottish Parliament to ensure its legislation is compatible with European law. For the UK to completely leave the EU, it would need to remove that obligation. If the UK Parliament wishes to legislate on policy areas devolved to Scotland, or if it wishes to amend the powers devolved to Scotland, by convention it needs the Scottish Parliament to pass a "legislative consent motion".
4.  Media reports suggested this might give the Scottish Parliament a veto over UK withdrawal from the EU, but under the Scotland Act 1998 the UK Parliament could ultimately override the "veto" as it is based only on parliamentary convention.

After a summit of EU leaders on 29 June, Sturgeon held meetings with some EU officials. She raised the possibility of parts of the UK remaining within the EU, or for these areas to have special arrangements with the EU, after the UK leaves. David Edward, a former justice of the European Court of Justice, suggested that these arrangements would relate to policy areas that have been devolved to Scotland.

Manfred Weber, leader of the European People's Party Group, and Guy Verhofstadt, leader of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group, indicated that they were supportive of Scotland remaining an EU member. The question seems to assume that "Scotland" can set a date for another referendum on independence. An Independence referendum is a UK Constitutional matter. Constitutional matters have not been devolved to the Scottish Parliament ("Scotland") but are reserved by the UK Parliament in Westminster. Therefore before Scotland could set a date for a referendum the Westminster Parliament would have to pass legislation authorising  it. There seems to be no appetite by the UK government to authorise another referendum. 
Therefore in order for anyone to set a date for another referendum would require (a) The Scottish Parliament to decide that there was a very high probability of winning a 2nd independence referendum (b) the Scottish government demanding that events had meant that the results of the first referendum should be ignored and request that Westminster authorise a 2nd referendum  (c) something to happen to change the UK government's mind. 
Although the UK has voted for Brexit, which could be considered grounds for holding a 2nd referendum, as yet it is totally unclear what form Brexit will be (or indeed if it will actually happen). Until it is clear what form  Brexit will take it will remain equally unclear what impact, if any, it would have on Scotland there are not really any grounds for holding a 2nd Scottish referendum.
Coupled with this the problems that are arising from having a Brexit referendum that only established what the voters did not want (they did not want to be in the EU) but did not actually establish what relationship, if any, voters wanted the UK to have with the EU. It can now be seen that there is a very high probability that having voted for Brexit, whatever relationship between the UK and EU results, a majority of voters will be unhappy with the outcome (e.g. if 48% did not want to leave, 10% want no deal with the EU at all, 10% want to be in the EEA, and 32% want some other arrangement then it will not be possible to give the majority what they want). The 1st Scottish referendum was a vague as the UK EU referendum, now with the benefit of the Brexit vote it is likely that Scottish Independence voters would want to vote for something more concrete than just leaving the UK, they would expect to be voting for a specific relationship with both the UK and EU.    
It is probable that by July 2017 it will still be unclear what the relationship between the UK and EU will be.
